header_summary:
Keagan McClelland proposes that wallets handle cryptocurrency "dust outputs" by converting them into additional transaction fees, a solution aimed at streamlining transactions and benefiting miners without altering the blockchain protocol. This approach necessitates careful integration to ensure user consent and a seamless experience, underscoring the importance of application-level innovation in resolving cryptocurrency transaction issues. [More details](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CALeFGL0ddgS=qCsunoGwD2j6By4_bQpndX-oKn_wAQse3o+Sxg@mail.gmail.com/T/#m9a9ef4bd1e7a6795ec3c2abc18650a8b0ca2f292)

Weikeng Chen highlights the need for enhanced programmability and privacy features in Bitcoin, emphasizing the crucial role of bridging solutions for protocol utilization beyond data availability. By introducing a comprehensive SNARK verification opcode, the proposed upgrades aim to facilitate rapid deployment and significantly improve Bitcoin's privacy capabilities, marking an important step toward addressing long-standing concerns within the digital currency ecosystem. [More information](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/b0afc5f2-4dcc-469d-b952-03eeac6e7d1b@gmail.com/T/#m566d1a8e33d45280bb1713b04ead37b5dc0be515)

Hunter Beast et al. discuss the implications of quantum computing on Bitcoin's security, focusing on developing quantum-resistant cryptographic methods and the importance of proactive measures against potential quantum threats. The conversation explores improvements to Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs), including the deployment of post-quantum cryptographic standards and defensive strategies to secure the network against quantum computing attacks. This forward-looking discussion underscores the collaborative effort required to protect digital assets in the quantum era. [Further reading](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/62fd28ab-e8b5-4cfc-b5ae-0d5a033af057n@googlegroups.com/T/#m21c31e17f014053cfefcc6c810bfa1c1781f6a7a)

The integration of BOLT12 into the main repository, as detailed by andyschroder, signifies progress in its development, with discussions on potential enhancements such as the addition of a `user` field and a `refund_invoice_required` option for offers. These discussions aim to refine BOLT12's functionality, demonstrating a collective effort to evolve the standard in response to real-world implementation challenges. [See the discussion](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/expanding-on-bolt12/1167)

recent_posts.title: OP_KEEPCHANGE - mitigating dust outputs
recent_posts.summary:
- Dust outputs in cryptocurrency cause user and technical policy issues due to impractical spending fees.
- A solution proposes wallet policies convert dust to fees, benefiting miners and improving transaction efficiency.
- Such wallet adjustments enhance user experience without altering the blockchain, emphasizing developer impact on application design.

recent_posts.title: Shielded CSV: Private and Efficient Client-Side Validation
recent_posts.summary:
- Bridging is a primary challenge for the protocol, needing effective solutions.
- BitVM technology may help, but the protocol requires further programmability enhancements.
- Introducing a SNARK verification opcode is vital for deployment on Bitcoin and enhancing privacy.

recent_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
recent_posts.summary:
- Recent discussions aim to enhance Bitcoin security against quantum computing threats.
- Proposals include soft forks and new cryptographic standards like FALCON signatures.
- Emphasizes the need for proactive measures to safeguard Bitcoin from quantum attacks.

recent_posts.title: Expanding on BOLT12
recent_posts.summary:
- BOLT12's integration into the main repository marks a significant advancement, prompting further enhancements.
- An optional `refund_invoice_required` field for `offer` writers could automate merchant refunds, enhancing efficiency.
- Introducing `offer_max_amount` and an expiration mechanism for `invoice_request`s could improve transaction management.

recent_posts.title: Proof-of-work based signet faucet
recent_posts.summary:
- The email highlights a unique Pay to Proof of Work (P2W) address in testnet4.
- It details a signature size check method, enhancing difficulty adjustment without consensus changes.
- The method utilizes P2WSH for compatibility, avoiding non-standard transactions efficiently.

recent_posts.title: Hybrid Jamming Mitigation: Results and Updates
recent_posts.summary:
- The document proposes a shift to prioritizing outgoing reputation for network transaction management.
- It introduces a bidirectional algorithm affecting transaction success based on outgoing reputation.
- Discusses practical implications for nodes, focusing on operations and network participation strategies.

active_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal introduces a new signature algorithm to add quantum resistance to Bitcoin.
- It begins a series of Bitcoin Improvement Proposals for a "QuBit" soft fork.
- Stakeholders are invited to review and provide feedback on the draft via a provided link.

active_posts.title: Shielded CSV: Private and Efficient Client-Side Validation
active_posts.summary:
- Liam Eagen, Robin Linus, and their team launched the Shielded CSV whitepaper for better CSV protocols.
- Shielded CSV uses "Proof-Carrying Data" for private, efficient cryptocurrency transactions, unlike traditional methods.
- The protocol represents a breakthrough in privacy and scalability, with a potential for 100 transactions per second on Bitcoin.

active_posts.title: OP_KEEPCHANGE - mitigating dust outputs
active_posts.summary:
- James Ferguson introduces "Keep the Change" to improve Bitcoin by using "OP_KEEPCHANGE".
- The mechanism credits small, unspendable Bitcoin amounts to the primary recipient to reduce waste.
- It aims to lower fees, enhance privacy, and stabilize Bitcoin's money supply by reducing dust outputs.

active_posts.title: Who will run the CoinJoin coordinators?
active_posts.summary:
- The crackdown on privacy tools has majorly impacted Bitcoin privacy services like Samourai and Wasabi Wallets.
- New solutions, including BTCPay Server's CoinJoin plugin, use the WabiSabi protocol to bolster privacy without centralized coordinators.
- The author's setting up of a BTCPay coordinator aims to address the low user adoption of alternative privacy solutions.

active_posts.title: SuperScalar: Laddered Timeout-Tree-Structured Decker-Wattenhofer Factories
active_posts.summary:
- The SuperScalar mechanism improves Bitcoin Lightning Network liquidity without blockchain consensus changes.
- It uses Decker-Wattenhofer mechanisms, timeout trees, and laddering strategies for scalability and security.
- The strategy involves organizing users into structured channels for efficient and adaptable liquidity management.

active_posts.title: Proving UTXO set inclusion in zero-knowledge
active_posts.summary:
- The `utxozkp` tool enhances LN channel announcement privacy by proving UTXO set inclusion.
- It remains a rough draft with a 6-minute proof generation time on an Apple M1 Max.
- Feedback is welcomed for future improvement; more details are available on the project's README.

today_in_history_posts.title: Is it possible for there to be two chains after a hard fork?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Gavin Andresen discusses Bitcoin's hard fork and using the old version.
- He questions the viability of supporting a 5% miner faction against the majority.
- Potential for exploiting the split raises concerns about the 5% fork's sustainability.

today_in_history_posts.title: Onion routing strawman proposal
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell shared test onion routing code on GitHub.
- The code is 3840 bytes and uses AES128, SHA256 HMAC, and Bitcoin EC with ECDH.
- Rusty requested a crypto review of this code.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant tools softfork
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The proposed softfork activates BIP-118, BIP-119, and BIP-345, enhancing Bitcoin's functionality.
- BIP-345's rapid deployment for Bitcoin vaults shows significant interest in safer custody methods.
- The implementation's manageable size suggests that reviewing and deploying it could be feasible with effort.
